stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on a craft-themed level for 'Return to Yoshi's Island.' Key activities included attempting to implement custom normal maps for styrofoam textures, redesigning mushroom platforms into paper plates based on community feedback, brainstorming new enemies, and planning out the level's various sections, ultimately pivoting from an ice area to a castle area for the finale.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is implementing a custom, CPU-based approximation of normal mapping to create dynamic lighting effects on textures like styrofoam, pushing the N64's original capabilities.
development_findings.quote: The N64 does not have normal map support. I added the support. The texture is computed on the CPU. And then the GPU just has to render it.

development_findings.summary: The level's final section was changed from an ice theme to a castle theme mid-stream after Kaze struggled with ideas for assets that fit the craft aesthetic.
In response to community feedback, the mushroom platforms were redesigned from a generic model to red paper plates with white dot decals, a solution Kaze was extremely pleased with.
development_findings.quote: Dude, these mushrooms are sexy... Oh my God, I love it. So cool.

development_findings.summary: The music from Mario Galaxy's Puzzle Plank Galaxy level served as direct inspiration for the desired feel of the game's platforming and led to the idea of falling cardboard bridges.
development_findings.quote: This song sounds like jumping, you know what I mean? And like fun.

development_findings.summary: A core design principle is making materials recognizable. Kaze emphasizes using lighting effects to help sell the 'realism' of the craft materials.
The team brainstormed several new enemies fitting the craft theme, including cardboard saw blades, cardboard Thwomps/Womps, and potentially a whiteboard eraser.
Kaze decided to incorporate popsicle sticks into the level design, starting with a small bridge, after discussing their potential use with the chat.
Kaze has a specific 'amateur doodle' art style in mind for the game's characters, and he initially felt a high-quality contribution from a fan clashed with this vision.
development_findings.quote: I was thinking the doodle characters in this were gonna look like really shittily drawn doodles... actually the problem with this is that it's too high quality.

context_findings.summary: Kaze revealed a long-standing dislike for 2D drawing, tracing back to his childhood, which contrasts with his current work in 3D modeling.
context_findings.quote: I remember on the last day of elementary school my teacher was like look how far you've come... And I said I still hate it. I'm just doing it so you leave me alone.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expressed a strong negative opinion on the popular Blender 'donut tutorial', believing it's ineffective for genuine learning and prefers learning from documentation.
context_findings.quote: The donut tutorial is useless unless you want to make a donut and don't know anything about blender.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shared a humorous but earnest philosophy that one should never antagonize the furry community, believing them to be talented, powerful, and deeply integrated into the tech world.
context_findings.quote: Furries are way too powerful. They're everywhere in tech, especially, and they're very talented... The furries are the one group of people you do not want to mess with.

context_findings.summary: Kaze received a $50 donation, which he noted could buy at least 10 burgers, giving a small insight into his local cost of living and appreciation for financial support.
Kaze and Zeina's personal relationship was mentioned in anecdotes, such as attempting to play Mario Kart together and watching the One Piece anime.

biobak.summary: Kaze stated that Biobak is assisting by reworking some of his levels, indicating a collaborative level design process.
Kaze actively sought Biobak's opinion on the new paper-plate mushroom design during the stream, showing he values his artistic input.
biobak.quote: I like this a lot, what do you think by a bank this sort of umbrella?

badub.summary: Kaze confirmed that Badub is responsible for making most of the music for the project.

zeina.summary: Zeina confirmed in the chat that she is designing the game's overworld, explaining the strategy of developing it later to ensure it cohesively integrates all the levels.
zeina.quote: I'm doing the overall just yes, the overall is the most important part. It will tie everything together and the later we do it the more information we have about the rest of the game.

key_stories.title: The Styrofoam Normal Map Problem
key_stories.summary: Kaze attempted to create realistic styrofoam using a custom, CPU-intensive normal mapping technique he developed for the N64. Despite the technical achievement, the visual result received mixed feedback, leaving the final look of the styrofoam unresolved.
key_stories.challenge: The community provided negative feedback on the appearance of the styrofoam mountains, particularly their color and texture.
key_stories.process: Kaze explained his custom implementation of a normal map-like effect on the N64 CPU. He adjusted the color to be whiter and debated the technical details with his chat, defending his choice to base the reflection on the camera angle for a more dynamic look.
key_stories.outcome: The feature remains a work-in-progress. While the dynamic lighting effect was implemented, Kaze received mixed feedback, with viewers noting the surfaces looked too flat and the block edges were too sharp, problems he acknowledged were limitations of the technique.
key_stories.key_quote: The N64 does not have normal map support. I added the support. The texture is computed on the CPU.

key_stories.title: The Paper Plate Mushroom Redesign
key_stories.summary: After the community criticized the old mushroom models, Kaze collaborated with his chat to brainstorm a new design. He settled on a paper plate concept, quickly found assets, and created a new model that he was incredibly proud of, turning a critique into a celebrated new asset.
key_stories.challenge: The original mushroom platforms in the level were considered ugly or low-resolution by the community.
key_stories.process: After acknowledging the feedback, Kaze solicited ideas from the chat. A user suggested paper umbrellas, which led Kaze to find a reference image of a paper plate craft. He then found a suitable red texture, modeled the plate, and used multi-texturing to apply the white dots as decals.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze created a new mushroom model based on a red paper plate with white dots, which he was extremely enthusiastic about. The new design was praised and replaced the old one.
key_stories.key_quote: Yes, your complaining was worth it. I am glad you were crying so much in my chat... Dude, these mushrooms are sexy.

key_stories.title: The 'Too Good' Yoshi Doodle
key_stories.summary: When a contributor's doodle was too well-drawn for the intended 'amateur' art style, Kaze adapted. He implemented the 2D art as a 3D object and developed a simple but effective vertex animation technique to make it feel like a piece of paper being bent and waved by hand.
key_stories.challenge: A contributor, Arthur, submitted a Yoshi doodle that was 'too high quality' and didn't fit the amateur, 'shittily drawn' aesthetic Kaze envisioned for the in-game characters.
key_stories.process: Despite his initial hesitation, Kaze decided to use the doodle. He modeled a flat plane with the texture and then devised a simple animation method. By subdividing the mesh and using basic vertex weighting, he was able to make the 2D cutout bend and wave as if it were being manipulated by hand.
key_stories.outcome: The doodle was successfully implemented as an animated NPC. Kaze's simple rigging solution worked well, creating a charming effect of a 2D character bending and waving in 3D space.
key_stories.key_quote: I was thinking the doodle characters in this were gonna look like really shittily drawn doodles. You know what I mean? Like this... this is what I was thinking.

open_questions.context: Zeina confirmed in the chat that she is working on the game's overworld and that it's being developed last to better tie all the levels together.
questions: What is the core concept or theme of the overworld?
How does your creative process for the overworld differ from Kaze's level design process?
What are the challenges of creating an overworld that has to connect so many different level themes?
How do you and Kaze collaborate on ensuring the overworld and the levels feel like part of the same game?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that Biobak helps him by 'reworking' some of the levels. He also specifically asked for Biobak's opinion on the new mushroom design.
questions: What does the 'level rework' process involve?
Can you give an example of a level or section you significantly changed or improved?
How do you and Kaze resolve creative differences when they arise?
What is the balance between executing Kaze's vision and injecting your own style?

open_questions.context: Kaze and the chat brainstormed numerous enemy ideas fitting the craft theme, such as cardboard saw blades, scissors, and Thwomps, but none were implemented.
questions: What is the process for taking an enemy from a concept like 'cardboard saw blade' to a fully functional opponent in the game?
Who is primarily responsible for programming the enemy AI and behaviors?
What are the biggest technical hurdles when creating new enemies in the SM64 engine?
How do you decide which enemies are fun and which ones are just frustrating?

open_questions.context: Kaze made a significant design pivot during the stream, abandoning the planned ice/volcano section in favor of a castle-themed area, but he ended the stream before designing it.
questions: What was the final reason for choosing a castle theme over ice or a volcano?
What are the key platforming mechanics or ideas you plan to introduce in this castle section?
How will the castle theme be represented using craft materials?

open_questions.context: Kaze confirmed that Badub creates most of the music. During the stream, Kaze praised the Mario Galaxy 'Puzzle Plank' OST as 'perfection' for a 3D platformer.
questions: How does the collaboration process for music work?
Does Kaze provide reference tracks or just a description of the level's feel?
How much creative freedom do you have when composing for a level?
How did you approach the soundtrack for this specific craft-themed world?
